presentation.title: CloudEvents: One Event to Rule Them All
presentation.toc: API management and governance in API landscapes are distinctively different from just looking at individual APIs. All the aspects of individual API apply as well, but there is the added aspect of achieving some coherence across the landscape. With this coherence, API designers and producers can more easily reuse design pattern and tooling, whereas API consumers can more easily understand APIs because they share design principles and building blocks. In the case of Event-Driven Architecture (EDA), the boundaries between APIs tend to be more blurry anyways because quite often event brokers are part of the landscape. CloudEvents establish a vocabulary and representations for describing event data across events and event producers. We'll take a look at the standard itself and at the most important vocabulary terms.

slide.title: CloudEvents: Managing Events in Event Landscapes

ol.li: Create a model for context attributes that describe events
Define an extension model for extension attributes
Map context and extension attributes into event format encodings
Create protocol bindings for protocols supporting message metadata
Provide support for consistent versioning of events

ul.li: Unified model of events across formats and messaging fabrics
Easier integration of events across various technologies
Better Function-as-a-Service (FaaS) portability across FaaS platforms
Better opportunities for Tooling to benefit from the unified model
Foundation for specific event-oriented models such as Webhooks
Easier policy enforcement across the landscape and between systems
id (String): Uniquely identifies the event (for a given source)
source (URI-reference): Identifies the context in which an event happened
specversion (String): The CloudEvents specification version (currently 1.0)
type (String): Identifies the type of event that happened
datacontenttype (String): Identifies the content type of the data value
dataschema (URI): Identifies the schema of the data value
subject (String): Identifies the event subject below source level
time (Timestamp): Timestamp of when the occurrence happened
CloudEvents have to be mapped into a specific event format
All implementations must support the JSON format
Avro and Protobuf formats are available as well
Protocol bindings describe how events are sent and received over a given protocol
Currently existing bindings are for AMQP, HTTP, Kafka, MQTT, NATS, and WebSockets
Content modes can describe different ways of how to deliver events
Structured content mode represents events in the way defined by a format
Binary content mode places attributes in protocol metadata (e.g., HTTP header fields)
Batched content mode has to be supported by batch-friendly formats
AsyncAPI focuses on describing event-based APIs
CloudEvents focuses on unifying events across event-based APIs
Combining the two is a good idea for complex API/EDA landscapes
Structured content mode requires payload to carry CloudEvents data
AsyncAPI structure will look as usual
AsyncAPI messages have to conform with CloudEvents
Binary content mode requires protocols to carry CloudEvents data
HTTP has to accommodate CloudEvents data
AsyncAPI traits are a useful mechanism for reusable message data
AsyncAPI messages specify the event data
Make CloudEvents part of your API guidelines
Provide tooling for API designers, developers, and consumers
Make sources and types easily findable for everybody
